loans.name: Kilisitina

texts.en:
Kilisitina P. is 36 and married with 5 children.  She owns a business venture selling pancakes and chips. Kilisitina has 2 years of experience in this business. Kilisitina needs a loan of 1000 WST to buy raw ingredients for cooked foods. She plans to use the earnings from her business (estimated to be 400 talas or US $167 per week) to improve/expand the business.

In 2010, Kilisitina joined SPBD.  This is her first loan with SPBD. SPBD's loans are Kilisitina's only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with traditional banks.

loans.use: To buy raw ingredients for cooked foods

loans.name: Malopule

texts.en:
Malopule A. F. is 37 and married with 6 children. She owns a business venture selling snack foods, vegetables, sacks of flour, sugar, rice and then she resell it to the local community. Malopule has 2 years of experience in this business. Malopule needs a loan of 1000 WST to purchase enough supplies of sugar, salt, onions, flour and rice.  She plans to use the earnings from her business (estimated to be 400 talas or US $167 per week) to improve/expand the business.

In 2010, Malopule joined SPBD. This is her first loan with SPBD. SPBD's loans are Malopule's only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with traditional banks.

loans.use: To purchase supplies of sugar, salt, onions, flour and rice,snacks and tomatoes and then sell it to the local community

loans.name: Las Manzanas De Peña Group

texts.es: Este grupo decidió ponerse el nombre de Las Manzanas de Peña ya que dicen ser tan dulces como una manzana, la comunidad donde viven se llama Monte de Peña y de ahi el nombre de Las Manzanas de Peña.  La señora Susana Macedonia es la Tesorera del grupo,ella tiene 45 años de edad, es casada y desde hace 5 años hace tortillas hechas a mano las cuales lleva a vender a otras comunidades;solicita crédito para ampliar su negocio,comprar algunas prensas,dos comales grandes, y contratar a una persona que le ayude ya que ella sola no alcanza a hacer todos los pedidos que se le requieren; con esto su negocio crecerá y las ganancias obtenidas serán mayores, más adelante piensa hacer mejoras en su vivienda.
texts.en:
This group decided to call themselves Las Manzanas de Peña (The Apples of Peña) because it's said they are as sweet as apples and because the community they live in is called Monte de Peña.  From there they got the name Las Manzanas de Peña.

Susana Macedonia is the group Treasurer.  She is 45 years old, is married and for five years has made handmade tortillas, which she takes to other communities to sell.  She is asking for a loan to expand her business by buying some tortilla presses, two large comals (griddles for cooking tortillas) and hiring someone to help her because she cannot fill all her orders alone.  With this loan her business will grow, and she will earn more money.  For the future Susana is thinking of making improvements to her house.

loans.use: Tortilla presses and 2 comals (griddles)

loans.name: Rosa

texts.es: Rosa, de 42 años, convive con Alejandro, de 45 años. Ambos tienen 3 hijos, pero solo viven con 2 de ellos: Denis, de 18 y Adeliz, de 17 años. En unión familiar ellos viven en su casa propia, ubicada en el caserío de Cumutay. El trabajo de está laboriosa mujer es la agricultura, donde siembra papa, arveja y maíz, ya tiene 32 años dedicándose a esto y según afirma le gusta mucho compartir momentos de dificultades y alegrías junto a su familia, ya que juntos se dirigen los fines de semana a limpiar, fertilizar y cosechar sus cultivos, porque los demás días de la semana se dedica al cuidado de su tienda de comestibles, donde vende productos de primera necesidad. Ya es conocida entre todo los pobladores del caserío, pues ofrece una variedad de productos necesarios para los alimentos del día. Ahora Rosa tiene pensado sembrar papa en gran escala, para poder comercializarlo en la capital del país, en temporada de campaña agrícola. Es el octavo crédito con MFP, y como secretaría de su banco comunal se siente honrada por ejercer un cargo dentro de su asociación. De obtener el crédito, lo invertirá en la compra de 12 sacos de abono orgánico, los cuales esparcirá en sus diferentes cultivos.
texts.en:
Rosa, 42, lives with Alejandro, 45.  They have three children, but they live with only two of them:  Denis, who is 18, and Adeliz, who is 17.  The family lives in their own house, which is located in the Cumutay settlement.

This hardworking woman is a farmer who grows potatoes, peas and corn.  She has been doing this work for 32 years and says she really likes to share both difficult times and happy moments with her family.  Together they weed, fertilize and harvest their crops on the weekends because the other days of the week Rosa works in her grocery store where she sells staple goods.  She is known by all the settlement's residents because she offers a variety of necessary products for people's daily food needs.  Now Rosa is thinking about growing potatoes on a large scale so she can sell them in the country's capital city during the harvest season.

This is Rosa's eighth loan with MFP.  She is secretary of her communal bank, and she feels honored to have this responsibility.  When she receives the loan, she will buy 12 sacks of organic fertilizer, which she will use on her various crops.

loans.use: Buy 12 sacks of organic fertilizer

loans.name: Taylor

texts.en:
Taylor F., age 35, provides general alteration and tailoring services in his local community. He has five years of experience in this business. He is unmarried and has no children.  

Taylor is requesting a loan of WST 1,000 in order to purchase additional tailoring equipment, such as needles and thread. He plans to use the improved earnings from his business (estimated to be 400 talas or US $167 per week) to improve and expand the business.

In 2010, Taylor joined SPBD.  This is his first loan with SPBD. SPBD's loans are Taylor's only access to capital because he was never able to qualify for a loan with traditional banks.

loans.use: To purchase additional tailoring equipment such as needles and thread

loans.name: Ana

texts.es: Ana, de 35 años, está casada con Jhon, de 37 años. Ambos tiene 2 hijos: Edu, de 13 y Didie, de 3 años de edad. En unión familiar ellos viven en su casa propia, ubicada en la ciudad de San Ramón (selva central peruana). Como docente, Ana trabaja enseñando a niños menores de 3 años en un jardín particular hace más de 8 años; pero la actividad que más le gusta a está laboriosa mujer son las hermosas manualidades como, angelitos, peluches, y muñecas a base de corrospun, micro poroso, telas y cintas; según explica vende la docena de angelitos a un promedio de 40 soles, los cuales le dan una rentabilidad mayor del 50% de lo invertido, pero en esta temporada de verano, Ana también brinda clases a los niño y adolescentes que quieren aprender el arte de las manualidades, donde pueden hacer volar su imaginación; principal cualidad de este negocio que según sus propias palabras, “es su pasatiempo”. Ahora ella quiere abrir una escuela de manualidades durante todo el año. Es el séptimo crédito con MFP, y según afirma está agradecida por el apoyo que durante todo este tiempo recibió de parte de su banco comunal donde cada reunión que tienen, celebran el cumpleaños de sus respectivas socias. De obtener el crédito, podrá adquirir materiales para la elaboración de sus manualidades, y si el dinero le alcanza lo invertirá en pagar sus capacitaciones de manualidades en la capital del país.
texts.en:
Ana, who is 35 years old, is married to Jhon, who is 37.  They have two children:  Edu,13, and Didie, 3.  The family lives in their own house in the city of San Ramón (in Peru's central jungle).

Ana has worked as a teacher for more than eight years, teaching children younger than 3 years old in a special class.  But this hardworking woman's favorite activity are the beautiful crafts she makes, such as angels, plush toys and dolls.  She makes them from corrospun (a type of plastic), craft foam, fabric and ribbon.  She says she sells a half-dozen angels for an average of 40 soles, which gives her a profit of more than 50% over the amount she invested in making them; but in this summer season, Ana is also offering classes to children and teenagers who want to learn to make crafts, where they can let their imaginations soar.  Imagination is a key quality for this business which, in Ana's own words, "is her hobby."  Ana wants to open a craft school year-round.

This is her seventh loan with MFP, and she says she is grateful for the support she has received all this time from her communal bank, which celebrates its members' birthdays at every meeting.  When she receives the loan, she will be able to buy craft materials, and if the money stretches far enough she will use it to pay for her training sessions in craft-making, which are held in the country's capital.

loans.use: Buy craft-making materials

loans.name: Brisa Del Mar Group

texts.es: Este grupo se llama Brisa del Mar porque se consideran personas cálidas como L. brisa. Está ubicado en el Estado D. TlaxcaL.. El grupo está conformado por 9 integrantes. Flora es L. tesorera del grupo. Tiene 26 años, estudió hasta el  3er año  D. secundaria, su negocio es L. venta D. ropa, tiene en total 3 hijos: 2 mujeres y 1 varón.  ElL. venD. ropa D. bebe, también se dedica a elaborar pantalones D. mezclilL.. Flora se separo D. su pareja y se quedo como único sustento económico D. sus 3 hijos. Se ha esmerado estos años para sacar adelante a sus pequeños hijos con L. ayuda D. su mamá, ha podido vencer las adversidades que se le han presentado durante estos años,  venD. en diferentes poblaciones desD. hace 6 años. Solicita el préstamo para comprar más ropa. Sus clientes son el público en general.  Al momento D. solicitar este préstamo se siente entusiasmada con muchas ganas D. tener éxito en este nuevo año. Quiere este crédito para L. compra D. ropa y teL. para L. elaboración D. pantalones.   También espera con este préstamo obtener mejores ganancias y así  más clientes ya que con eso le permitirá  tener una mejor calidad D. vida para  elL. y su familia.
texts.en:
This group is called Brisa del Mar (Ocean Breeze) because the members are known to be as warm as the breeze.  The group is located in the State of TlaxcaL. and has nine members.

Flora is the group treasurer.  She is 26 years old.  She studied up to the third year of high school, and her business is clothing sales.  She has three children:  two girls and one boy.  She sells baby clothes and makes denim jeans.  Flora separated from her partner and is now the only financial support for her three children.  With her mother's help, she has gone to a lot of trouble in these years to give her children a good start in life.  She has been able to overcome the setbacks she's faced during these years.  For the past six years, Flora has maD. sales in several towns.  She is asking for the loan to buy more clothing.  Her customers are the general public.  When she asked for the loan, she felt excited and ready to make this new year a successful one.  Flora wants this loan to buy clothing and fabric for making jeans.  She also hopes to have higher earnings and more customers because of this loan, so she can have a better quality of life for herself and her family.

loans.use: Purchase of clothing and of fabric for making pants

loans.name: Ciria

texts.es: Ciria, de 57 años, es una valerosa madre soltera de 3 hijos, de los cuales solo vive con uno de ellos: Luis, de 23 años, en su casa propia, ubicada en la ciudad de San Ramón (selva central peruana). El trabajo al que se dedica está luchadora mujer es la venta de ropa importada en las feria que se realiza constantemente en la ciudad, donde los pobladores esperan ansiosa la llegada de Ciria, que trae ropas novedosas y de moda, según afirma viaja una vez al mes para comprar ropa importada que le cuestan un promedio de 700 dólares. Ya tiene 2 años dedicándose a ello, y le va tan bien que ahora viaja a las ciudades de Pichanaki y Villa Rica, pero a pesar de su éxito, ella también tiene una tienda de comestibles en su casa. Ahora Ciria, quiere ampliar su negocio, con la apertura de una tienda de ropas en el centro de la ciudad. Es el octavo crédito con MFP, y conocedora del trabajo que se realiza en su banco comunal, se siente segura de poder contar con personas responsables y muy comprometidas. De obtener el crédito, podrá comprar diversas prendas de vestir para damas, caballeros y niños, los cuales venderá en está temporada.
texts.en: Ciria, age 57, is a courageous single mother of 3 children, of whom only one lives with her in her own home: Luis, age 23. Her home is in the city of San Ramon (in the central Peruvian tropical forest). This hard-working woman sells imported clothing in the markets that are constantly happening in the city. The villagers eagerly await her, as she brings original and stylish clothing. She says that she travels once a month to purchase imported clothing that costs an average of 700 dollars. She has been doing this for 2 years, and it is going so well that she now travels to the cities if Pichanaki and Villa Rica. However, despite her success, she also has a food store in her home. Ciria wants to expand her business with the opening of a clothing store in the city center. This is her eighth loan with MFP, and as she knows the work that goes on in her community bank, so she is certain that she can count on responsible and dedicated people. When she obtains this loan, she will be able to purchase diverse articles of clothing for women, men and children, which she will sell this season.

loans.use: to purchase various clothing articles for women, men and children.

loans.name: 21 De Diciembre Group

texts.es:
La B.C. “21 de Diciembre” iniciará su  onceavo ciclo en Pro Mujer, como parte del Centro Focal de Cascada, han superado este ciclo, identificado sus virtudes y debilidades.  Está compuesta por once integrantes.  Los negocios que ellas desempeñan son variados: tejido de chompas a ganchillo, artesanía de tejido en mantas, venta de verduras, artesanía de tejido a mano, costura de prendas deportivas, transporte, macramé.

La señora Dionicia, presidenta de la banca comunal, indica que forma parte del B.C. “21 de Diciembre” desde hace diez ciclos, aproximadamente cinco años. Casada, madre de tres hijos, su negocio es el de macramé, desde hace más de ocho años, ella aprendió a realizar esta artesanía pasando un curso auspiciado por la Radio Inca,  a partir de los puntos básicos de macramé que aprendió ahora la señora Dionicia puede crear sus propios diseños.  Esta habilidad le permite seguir la moda de macramé en mantas de chola, que según indica cambia cada tres meses.  El crédito que ha solicitado le permitirá comprar tela y flecadura. Actualmente elabora su producto a pedido de sus clientes, de esta manera no necesita un puesto de venta y al permanecer en su domicilio puede cuidar de sus hijos y de su hogar.

Cuando se le consulta que le gusta de Pro Mujer, ella comenta que le gusta la oportunidad de compartir con sus compañeras.
texts.en:
The 21 de Diciembre communal bank will begin its eleventh loan cycle at Pro Mujer. As part of the Casada Community Center, they have completed this cycle and have identified their strengths and weaknesses. The group consists of eleven members and their businesses are varied: crocheting sweaters, knitting blankets, selling vegetables, hand-knitting handicrafts, sewing sports clothing, transportation, macramé.

Dionicia, the president of the communal bank, indicates that she has been part of 21 de Diciembre communal bank for ten loan cycles, or approximately five years. She is married, the mother of three children, and her business has been macramé for more than eight years. She learned to make this handicraft in a course sponsored by Radio Inca. From the macramé basics that she learned, Dionicia can now create her own designs. This skill allows her to follow macramé fashion in ‘chola’ blankets, which changes every three months according to her. The loan that she has requested will allow her to purchase fabric and fringe. She currently makes her product at the request of her customers and this way, she doesn’t need a place of sales and in staying home, she can take care of her children and her home.

When asked what she likes about Pro Mujer, she commented that she likes the opportunity to share with her fellow group members.

loans.use: To purchase fabric and fringe

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: working capital

loans.name: Marcolfa Emperatriz

texts.es:
En la ciudad de Portoviejo, capital de Manabí conocida desde hace muchos años  como la ciudad de los reales tamarindos, se reúnen cada quince días  las socias del Banco Comunal Luz y Progreso.

Aquí conversamos con la señora Marcolfa, tiene 41 años de edad,  está casada  y tiene tres hijos de  23,  17 y 15 años que  estudian en Universidad y  en colegio. Su esposo es peluquero. Está  en el Banco Comunal hace tres años,  es la presidenta del mismo y esto lo ha tomado con mucha responsabilidad, le gusta porque estos créditos la han ayudado mucho así como a sus compañeras del grupo.

Tiene una pequeña fábrica donde elabora conos de galleta para helados, trabaja de lunes a sábado desde las 8h00 hasta las 17h00, sus hijos le ayudan en esta labor, una vez que estos deliciosos conos están listos los entregan en su local a vendedores de helados y heladerías de la localidad, nos cuenta que esta labor la aprendió de su mama desde muy joven y que ya lleva en este negocio por más de 15 años y que le ha ido muy bien.

Este crédito es para comprar materiales e ingredientes para elaborar los conos. Sus sueños son tener una gran empresa y terminar su casa que la tiene en construcción.
texts.en:
In the city of Portoviejo, capital of Manabí, known for many years as the city of the real tamarinds, the members of the Banco Comunal Luz y Progreso meet every 5 days.

This is where we met Marcolfo, 41 years old, married with three children aged 23,17 and 15 that study in the University and high school. Her husband is a barber. She has been in the Banco Communal for more than three years, is the president of the same and this has given her a lot of responsibility. She enjoys it because the loans have really helped her as much as her companions in the group.

She has a small workshop where she makes ice cream cones. She works Monday to Saturday from 8:00 until 17:00. Her children help her work. When the delicious cones are ready, they deliver them in their neighborhood to local ice cream shops. She tells us that she learned this from her mother since a young age and has worked in this business for more than 15 years. It has served her well.

This loan is to purchase materials and ingredients to make cones. Her dreams are to have a big business and finish the house that she has in construction.

loans.use: To purchase flour, eggs, sugar, water, etc...

loans.name: Gleidis Policarpa

texts.es: La señora Gleidis Policarpa T. Y. tiene 36 años y vive en compañía de sus padres y sus dos hijos en el barrio Bellavista de Malambo, perteneciente al área metropolitana de Barranquilla. Se dedica al comercio de ropa, calzado, perfumes, electrodomésticos menores y artesanías. Estas últimas las compra en el municipio de San Jacinto, una pintoresca localidad enclavada en el centro del departamento de Bolívar y famosa por sus sombreros, mochilas y hamacas. La señora Gleidis heredó el negocio de su mamá, que era una veterana comerciante y por motivos de salud debió retirarse del oficio. Tiene una clientela acreditada que ha logrado conservar por más de 10 años. Al principio tuvo problemas de morosidad, pero después empezó a ser selectiva y fue escogiendo los clientes que mejor le pagaban. Hoy dice con orgullo que no tiene problemas con la recuperación de la cartera. Este es el segundo préstamo que tramita con la Fundación Mario Santo Domingo y planea invertirlo en la compra de Jeans, camisas, pantalones y artesanías. El dinero del préstamo anterior, que fue de $ 1.000.000 COP,  se lo robaron totalmente unos delincuentes cuando se disponía a viajar a San Jacinto. Esto la afectó mucho anímica y econonómicamente, pero con la ayuda de algunos amigos logró pagar la deuda y capitalizar su negocio, aunque confiesa que tuvo que restringir drásticamente sus gastos familiares. El promedio de ventas mensuales es de $1.400.000, el margen de utilidad es del 35% y el plazo que le otorga a sus clientes para pagar es de 45 a 60 días. La señora Gleidis se muestra optimista hacia el futuro porque en el mes de febrero comienza la temporada del carnaval de Barranquilla, la más importante fiesta folclórica de Colombia, y los pedidos de sombreros y mochilas aumentan considerablemente.
texts.en:
Gleidis Policarpa T. Y. is 36 years old and lives with her parents and her two children in a neighborhood called Bellavista de Malambo in the metropolitan area of Barranquilla. She works selling clothing, shoes, perfume, small electrical appliances, and handicrafts. She buys these items in San Jacinto, a picturesque town located in the center of the department of Bolívar, which is famous for its hats, bags, and hammocks. 

Gleidis inherited the business from her mother, a veteran saleswoman who had to retire because of health problems. Her customers are renowned and she has kept them coming back for more than ten years. Initially she had some problems with customers making late payments but then she got more selective and started choosing those customers who paid her the best. Today she is proud to report that she no longer has any trouble securing payment.

This will be the second loan that she has received through Fundación Mario Santo Domingo. She plans to use the funds to purchase jeans, shirts, pants, and handicrafts. The previous loan that she received was for 1,000,000.00 Colombian pesos. Robbers stole the entire loan from her just as she was getting ready to travel to San Jacinto. This took an emotional and economic toll on her but with the help of a few friends, she was able to pay off the debt and fund her business. However, she confesses that she had to make drastic cuts to her household expenses.

Her average monthly sales total 1,400,000.00 Colombian pesos and her profit margin is 35%. She gives her customers 45 to 60 days to pay her. Gleidis is optimistic about the future because February is when the Barranquilla carnival begins. This is the most important folk music festival in Colombia and the demand for hats and bags increases considerably.

loans.use: Purchase of jeans, shirts, pants and handicrafts.

loans.name: Celia Maria

texts.es:
En la ciudad de Portoviejo, capital de Manabí conocida desde hace muchos años  como la ciudad de los reales tamarindos, se reúnen cada quince días  las socias del Banco Comunal Luz y Progreso.

La señora  Celia forma parte del Banco Comunal desde hace 6 años y está muy contenta con los beneficios que ha recibido de la institución. Ella tiene 51 años de edad, está casada y de esta relación tiene tres hijos, dos de ellos son mayores de edad y el ultimo tiene 15 años y estudia en colegio dos de sus hijos viven en su casa. Su marido instala y vende centrales telefónicas.
 
Es una muy buena ama de casa que además se dedica al comercio, vende productos Yanbal (cosméticos, productos de belleza, perfumería y accesorios para damas) trabaja los viernes, sábados y domingos desde las 7am hasta las 12pm, aunque sus clientes también llegan hasta su casa y les vende a cualquier hora. Lo que más vende son los perfumes y los cosméticos.

Este crédito lo va a emplear en comprar productos Yanbal como perfumes, cremas, cosméticos, y una parte es para el negocio del esposo. Sus sueños son tener su casa propia ya que donde vive es alquilado
texts.en:
In the city of Portoviejo, capital of Manabí, known for many years as the city of the real tamarinds, meet the members of the Banco Comunal Luz y Progreso every fifteen days.

Celia is part of the Banco Comunal for more than 6 years, and she is really content with the benefits that she has received with this institution. She is 51 years old, married and has 3 children with her husband, two of whom are older and the last is 15 years old and studies in high school. Two of her children live at home. Her husband installs and sells telephones. She is a very good heart of the home and also works selling Yanbal products (cosmetics, beauty products, perfume and women’s accessories). She works Fridays, Saturdays and Sundays from 7am until 12pm, although her customers also come to her home, and she sells to them at any hour. The products that she sells most are perfumes and cosmetics.

This loan will be used to purchase Yanbal products such as perfumes, creams, cosmetics, and part will be use for her husband’s business. Her dreams are to have her own home since the one where they live is rented.

loans.use: To purchase creams, perfumes and cosmetics as well as telephone systems

loans.name: Costeñitas Ii Group

texts.es:
La B.C. “Costeñitas” iniciará su  cuarto ciclo en Pro Mujer, como parte del Centro Focal de Villa Exaltación.  Está compuesta por diez integrantes.  Los negocios que ellas desempeñan son variados: venta de cosméticos, venta de cerveza, tienda surtida, kiosko dentro de un colegio, venta de ropa, comercio, venta de dulces, pensión, carpintería, venta de perfumes y víveres, venta de ropa.

La señora Amanda, presidenta de la banca comunal, indica que forma parte de la B.C. “Costeñitas”  dos ciclos, aproximadamente un año, con un periodo de descanso entre el primer y segundo ciclo.  Actualmente divorciada, madre de dos hijos, su negocio es la compra venta de ropa interior. Hace nueve años la señora Amanda perdió su trabajo, tiempo en el que decidió seguir el consejo de una amiga y viajar para traer ropa interior de Iquique ciudad en la costa Chilena y venderla de manera ambulante en instituciones privadas y públicas.  Este negocio le permitió cuidar a sus hijos, su hogar, disponer de su tiempo de la mejor manera.

El crédito que ha solicitado le permitirá viajar a la ciudad de Iquique a recoger la mercadería que ya encargó para fin de año: ropa íntima de color rojo y amarillo,  respondiendo a la creencia de que si uno viste ropa íntima de color rojo tendrá el amor esperado o si viste ropa en color amarillo este año no faltará el dinero en el bolsillo.

Cuando se le consulta que le gusta de Pro Mujer, ella comenta que el crédito y las cuotas quincenales le son muy cómodas.
texts.en:
The "Costeñitas" communal bank will start its fourth cycle with Pro Mujer, as part of the Villa Exaltación regional office.  It is made up of ten members.  Their businesses are varied: selling cosmetics, selling beer, running a grocery store, running a stand inside a school, selling clothing, running a store, selling candy, lodging, carpentry, and selling perfume and provisions.

Amanda, president of the communal bank, has been part of the "Costeñitas" communal bank for two cycles, approximately one year.  She took a break between the first and second cycle.  Currently divorced and the mother of two children, her business is the buying and selling of underwear.  Nine years ago, Amanda lost her job, and that's when she decided to follow the advice of a friend and make a trip to bring underwear from Iquique, a city on the Chilean coast, and travel around selling it to private and public institutions.  This business allows her to care for her children and her home, and make the best use of her time.

The loan she has requested will allow her to travel to the city of Iquique to collect the merchandise that she has already ordered for the end of the year: red and yellow underwear.  This is in response to the belief that if one wears red underwear, one will have the love they hope for, and if one wears yellow underwear, this year there will always be money in one's wallet.

When asked what she likes about Pro Mujer, she notes that the loan and the bimonthly payments are very comfortable for her.

loans.use: Purchase of underwear

loans.name: Rosa Virginia

texts.es:
En la ciudad de Portoviejo, capital de Manabí conocida desde hace muchos años  como la ciudad de los reales tamarindos, se reúnen cada quince días  las socias del Banco Comunal Luz y Progreso.

La señora Rosa es socia fundadora hace 15 años del Banco comunal y le gusta por los beneficios adicionales que brinda la institución y por las facilidades para los créditos. Tiene 73  años de edad, está casada y de esta relación tiene 13 hijos los cuales ya son mayores de edad pero uno de ellos  vive con ella. Su esposo es comerciante.

Tiene un puesto en la calle chile en Portoviejo en el cual vende todo tipo de especias como: pimienta, comino, entre otros. Además también vende detergentes, desodorantes y otros productos. Trabaja todos los días desde las 6h00 hasta las 18h00, nos cuenta que lleva más de 30 años que se dedica a esta actividad y que gracias a Dios esto le ha dado para ayudar a su esposo en los gastos de su familia. Sus productos los compra en una distribuidora en el centro de la ciudad de Portoviejo.

Este crédito lo va a emplear en comprar más de sus productos, especias, detergentes, entre otros. Sus sueños siempre han sido tener una tienda para ya no trabajar en la calle.
texts.en:
Members of the community bank Light and Progress gather every fifteen days In the city of Portoviejo, capital of Manabí, which has been known for many years as the city of the royal tamarinds.

Rosa founded the community bank fifteen years ago. She likes the facility of obtaining loans and the additional benefits the institution offers.  She is 73 years old and married.  With her husband, she has 13 grown children, one of whom still lives with her.  Her husband is a storekeeper.

Rosa has a shop stall on the street in Portoviejo where she sells all types of spices like pepper and cumin among others.  She also sells detergents, deodarants, and other products.  She works every day from 6AM to 6PM.  She tells us she has been selling for more than 30 years, and thanks to God her work has allowed her to help her husband support their family.  She buys her products from a distributor in downtown Portoviejo.

Rosa will use this loan to buy more products, like spices and detergents, among others.  Her dreams have always been to have a store so that she no longer has to work selling in the street.

loans.use: Buying spices, detergents, deodarant, etc.

loans.name: Mitai

texts.en:
For the past year, Mitai P. I., age 34, has been making and selling pancakes to members of her local community. Mitai needs a loan of WST 1,000 to buy a sack of flour, sugar, baking powder, and a large frying pan. She plans to use the increased earnings from her business (estimated to be 400 talas or US $167 per week) to improve and expand the business. She and her husband have four children.

In 2010, Mitai joined SPBD. This is her first loan with SPBD. SPBD's loans are Mitai's only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with traditional banks.

loans.use: To buy a sack of flour, sugar, baking powder, and a large frying pan

loans.name: Ututaaloga

texts.en:
Anarosa  Keli, age 56, sells ice-cakes and pancakes in her local community. Anarosa has two years of experience in this business. Anarosa needs a loan of WST 1,000 to buy flavoring, sugar, and foam cups, as well as sacks of flour and baking powder. She plans to use the increased earnings from her business (estimated to be 200 talas or US $83 per week) to improve and expand her business.

In 2009, Anarosa  joined SPBD. This is her second loan with SPBD. SPBD's loans are Anarosa 's only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with traditional banks.

loans.use: To buy flavoring, sugar, and foam cups, as well as sacks of flour and baking powder

loans.name: Julia Adelaida

texts.es:
En la ciudad de Portoviejo, capital de Manabí conocida desde hace muchos años  como la ciudad de los reales tamarindos, se reúnen cada quince días  las socias del Banco Comunal Luz y Progreso.

En este lugar encontramos a la señora Julia, tiene 54 años de edad y mantiene una relación de unión libre de la cual tiene siete  hijos todos mayores de edad, dos de ellos viven en su casa, también con ella vive un nieto de seis años que es como su hijo y que estudia en la escuela. El marido es comerciante de pescado.
 
Se dedica a la venta de ropa por catalogo dice que le encanta vender.  También tiene una  mini tienda de viveras de consumo,  como arroz, azúcar, aceites, detergentes, etc. en la cual trabaja todos los días desde las 6am hasta las 20h00 y a veces hasta más tarde, en ella vende también  la ropa ya que la mayoría de sus clientes siempre compran en su tienda lugar que aprovecha para mostrar sus productos de catalogo. Sus productos los recibe en su local.

Este crédito lo va a emplear en surtir más su tienda, va a comprar arroz, azúcar, aceite, detergentes, embutidos y en ropa ya que tiene varios encargos. Está en el Banco Comunal hace 11 años y le gusta porque los créditos le han ayudado mucho. Sus metas son tener una casa bien arreglada y hacer una cisterna porque donde ella vive no hay agua potable.
texts.en:
The Luz y Progreso communal bank meets every 15 days in the city of Portoviejo, which is the capital of Manabí and has been known for many years as the “City of the Royal Tamarind Trees.”

This is where we find Julia, who is 54 years old and has a common-law marriage from which she has seven children. All of her children are now adults and two of them live in her house, as well as a 6-year-old grandson who is like her son and is a student. Her husband is a fish merchant.

She works selling clothing from a catalog and says that she loves to sell. She also has a mini-grocery store where she sells rice, sugar, oil, detergent, etc. and works every day from 6am to 8pm, sometimes later. There, she also sells the clothing since the majority of her customers always buy in her store where she takes advantage of the opportunity to show her catalog products. Her products are delivered to her store.

She will use this loan to further stock her store by purchasing rice, sugar, oil, detergents, and cold cuts, as well as clothing since she already has several orders. She has been with the communal bank for 11 years and she likes it because the loans have helped her greatly. Her goals are to have a nice-looking house and to make a tank because there isn’t drinking water where she lives.

loans.use: To purchase rice, sugar, oil, detergents, cold cuts, and clothing

loans.name: Moeumu

texts.en:
Moeumu F., age 35, is a farmer. She plants and harvests taro for sale. Moeumu has many years of experience in this business. She needs a loan of WST 1,000 to purchase weed-killers such as Gramoxome. She plans to use the earnings from her business (estimated to be 500 talas or US $208 per week) to improve and expand the business. She and her husband have five children.

In 2008, Moeumu  joined SPBD.  This is her fourth loan with SPBD. SPBD's loans are Moeumu's only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with traditional banks.

loans.use: To purchase weed-killers such as Gramoxome for her taro crops

loans.name: Yina Del Rosio

texts.es:
En la ciudad de Portoviejo, capital de Manabí conocida desde hace muchos años  como la ciudad de los reales tamarindos, se reúnen cada quince días  las socias del Banco Comunal Luz y Progreso.

En este lugar encontramos a la señora Yina, tiene 37 años de edad, está casada y de esta relación tiene dos hijos de 12 y de 2 años y seis meses, el mayor esta en colegio. Su marido estudia en la Universidad.

Ella tiene una tienda de viveras de consumo vende productos como: arroz, azúcar, aceites, detergentes,  también venden ciertos artículos de bazar. Trabaja todos los días desde las 6am hasta las 20h00 y a veces hasta más tarde, su esposo le ayudan en su trabajo, los productos los compra en el centro de Portoviejo aunque la mayoría de sus productos los recibe en su local, nos cuenta que recién lleva dos años pero que tiene su tienda bien surtida.

Este crédito lo va a emplear en surtir mas su tienda, va a comprar arroz, azúcar, aceite, detergentes, embutidos y productos de basar. Está en el Banco Comunal hace 4 ciclos y le gusta porque los intereses son bajos. Sus metas son ampliar su despensa.
texts.en: Members of the Luz y Progreso (Light and Progress) Community Bank meet every 15 days in the city of Portoviejo, the capital of Manabí province that has long been known as the city with real tamarind. It is here we find Yina, who is 37 years old, married and has two children ages 12 and 2.5. The eldest one is in school. Her husband is studying at the university. Yina has a general store that sells products like rice, sugar, oils and detergents as wells as other bazaar products. She works every day from 6 a.m. until 8 p.m. and sometimes later. Her husband helps her with the work. She buys her products in the center of Portoviejo, although the majority of them she receives at her store. She tells us she has had the store for about two years and she keeps it well stocked. She plans to use the loan to further stock her store, purchasing rice, sugar, oil, detergents, sausages and other products. There are four loan cycles with this community bank, and she likes it because the interest rate is low. Her goal is to expand her store.

loans.use: Purchase rice, sugar, oil, detergent, sausages and general supplies

loans.name: Alborada Group

texts.es:
La B.C. “ALBORADA” iniciará el ciclo número diez y siete en Pro Mujer, como parte del Centro Focal de Villa Exaltación.  Está compuesta por ocho integrantes, la banca comunal está dirigida por una mesa directiva: una presidenta, tesorera y secretaria de actas.   Los negocios que las integrantes llevan adelante son variados: costura, tienda de barrio, venta de fruta, venta de artefactos, venta de ladrillos, venta de fruta, venta de jugos, venta de juguetes.

La señora María, tesorera de la banca comunal, indica que forma parte de la B.C. “Alborada”   13 ciclos, aproximadamente seis años y medio.  Actualmente separada, madre de dos hijos, su negocio es la venta de fruta.  La señora  María comenta que desde niña vendió fruta, primero con su madre y luego sola.  Su primer crédito fue de $us100 (Bs700) el que está solicitando en esta oportunidad es de Bs2000, en ambos casos está destinado a ser invertido en la compra de fruta.

Cuando se le consulta que le gusta de Pro Mujer, ella comenta que le gusta todo.
texts.en: The Alborada group is starting its seventeenth cycle in Pro Mujer, as part of the Villa Exaltacion central office. The group is made up of eight members. The community bank is directed by a board: a president, treasurer and a secretary. The members' businesses are varied: sewing, a grocery store, fruit sales, appliance sales, brick sales, fruit sales, games sales and toys sales. Maria, the community bank treasurer, says that she has been part of the Alborada group for 13 cycles, approximately six and a half years. She is currently separated. She is a mother of two children and her business is fruit sales. Maria says that she has sold fruit since she was a child, first with her mother and later alone. Her first loan was $100 US (700 bs). The loan that she is currently requesting is 2000 Bs. Both loans were to be invested in the purchase of fruit. When asked what she likes about Pro Mujer, she replied that she likes everything.

loans.use: the purchase of fruit

loans.name: Rosa Carmen

texts.es:
En la ciudad de Portoviejo, capital de Manabí conocida desde hace muchos años  como la ciudad de los reales tamarindos, se reúnen cada quince días  las socias del Banco Comunal Luz y Progreso.

Aquí conocimos a la señora Rosa ella es madre sotera de tres hijos los mismos que ya son mayores de edad, uno de ellos vive con ella. Está en el Banco Comunal hace 5 años y le gusta porque los intereses son bajos y porque en las reuniones aprende mucho, le encantan las charlas de salud.

Ella es una mujer a la que le encanta el trabajo, dice que si no realiza una actividad no  está bien. Se dedica a la cría de animales de corral en su casa, pero también vende productos Yanbal (artículos de belleza, cosméticos perfumería y accesorios para damas). Además de ropa por catalogo, trabaja todos los días desde las 8h30 hasta las 14h00. Su mercadería la compra en Portoviejo. También sabe  corte y confección.

Con este crédito quiere comprar una maquina overlok (máquina para hacer hilvanes) para dedicarse a elaborar sabanas. Sus sueños son  progresar en este nuevo negocio.
texts.en: Members of the Luz y Progreso (Light and Progress) Community Bank meet every 15 days in the city of Portoviejo, the capital of Manabí province that has long been known as the city with real tamarind. Here we find Rosa, a single mother of three adult children, one of whom lives with her. She has been with this community bank for five years and likes it because the interest rates are low and she learns a lot at the meetings, especially the chats about health. Rosa is a woman who loves to work. She says it is no good if she is not doing some activity. She makes a living raising farm animals out of her home, but she also sells Yanbal brand beauty products. She works every day from 8:30 a.m. until 2 p.m. and buys her merchandise in Portoviejo. She also knows how to sew and cut. With this loan she wants to purchase an overlock sewing machine so she can make a living making sheets. Her dream is to make progress with this new business.

loans.use: Purchase an overlock sewing machine

loans.name: Jessica Alexandra

texts.es:
En la ciudad de Portoviejo, capital de Manabí conocida desde hace muchos años  como la ciudad de los reales tamarindos, se reúnen cada quince días  las socias del Banco Comunal Luz y Progreso.

En este lugar encontramos a la señora Jessica, tiene 23 años de edad, está casada y de esta relación tiene una hermosa niña  de 3 años. Su marido es comerciante vende legumbres en el mercado Nº 1.

Se dedica a la venta productos por catálogos de Esika Y Lebel (artículos de belleza, cosméticos perfumería y accesorios para damas). Además de ropa por catalogo, trabaja tres días  a la semana desde las 8h30 hasta las 11h00, su forma de venta es puerta a puerta y tiene muchos clientes que le realizan sus pedidos deja a crédito y cobra semanalmente. Su mercadería la entrega en su casa.

Este crédito lo va a compartir, una mitad para comprar ropa, cremas, perfumes y la otra parte para el negocio del esposo para que compre frutas y legumbres. Está en el Banco Comunal hace 2 ciclos y le gusta por la facilidad para obtener los créditos. Sus metas son tener su casa propia ya que vive en casa de una hermana.
texts.en: Members of the Luz y Progreso (Light and Progress) Community Bank meet every 15 days in the city of Portoviejo, the capital of Manabí province that has long been known as the city with real tamarind. It is here we find Jessica, who is 23 years old, married and has a 3-year-old daughter. Her husband sells legumes at the local market. Jessica makes a living selling Esika and Lebel brand beauty products (cosmetics, perfumes, women's accessories) via catalog. She works three days a week from 8:30 to 11 a.m., selling items door to door, and she has a lot of customers who make orders on credit and have weekly payments. Her merchandise is delivered to her home. She plans to share the loan, with half going to buy clothing, lotions and perfumes, and the other half going to her husband to buy fruits and legumes for his business. This is her second loan with this community bank and she likes the simplicity in getting the loan. Her goal is to have her own home since she lives in her sister's house.

loans.use: Purchase lotions, perfumes, clothing, fruits and legumes

loans.name: Solaua

texts.en:
Solaua T., age 58, is a farmer. She plants and harvests bananas for sale. Solaua has three years of experience in this business. Solaua is requesting a loan of WST 1,500 to purchase general farm supplies and equipment. She plans to use the earnings from her business (estimated to be 300 talas or US $125 per week) to improve and expand her business. She and her husband have five children between the ages of 18 and 26.

In 2008, Solaua joined SPBD. This is her third loan with SPBD. SPBD's loans are Solaua's only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with traditional banks.

loans.use: To purchase general farm supplies and equipment

loans.name: Telesia

texts.en:
Telesia A., age 37, is a farmer, planting and harvesting taro and offering it for sale. Telesia has two years of experience in this business. Telesia needs a loan of WST 1,000 in order to purchase general farm supplies and equipment. She plans to use the earnings from her business (estimated to be 300 talas or US $125 per week) to improve and expand her business. She and her husband have six children between the ages of one and 15.

In 2010, Telesia joined SPBD. This is her first loan with SPBD. SPBD's loans are Telesia's only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with traditional banks.

loans.use: To purchase general farm supplies and equipment

loans.name: Flora

texts.en:
Flora S., age 33, is a farmer, planting and harvesting bananas and offering them for sale. Flora has three years of experience in this business. Flora needs a loan of WST $1,500 to purchase general farm supplies and equipment. She plans to use the earnings from her business (estimated to be 350 talas or US $146 per week) to improve and expand her business. She and her husband have five children.

In 2008, Flora joined SPBD. This is her third loan with SPBD. SPBD's loans are Flora's only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with traditional banks.

loans.use: To purchase general farm supplies and equipment

loans.name: Alatasi

texts.en:
AlaT. T., age 56, is a farmer, planting and harvesting bananas and offering them for sale. AlaT. has five years of experience in this business. AlaT. needs a loan of WST $2,500 to purchase general farm supplies and equipment. She plans to use the earnings from her business (estimated to be 320 talas or US $133 per week) to improve and expand her business. She and her husband have two children, ages five and nine.

In 2007, AlaT. joined SPBD. This is her fifth loan with SPBD. SPBD's loans are AlaT.'s only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with traditional banks.

loans.use: To purchase general farm supplies and equipment

loans.name: Heng

texts.en: Mrs. Heng S. supports her family by breeding and selling cows and chickens in the village of Peam Reang Kraom village in Kandal province. She was born in 1973. Her business is going well, and it is for this reason that she wants to expand. To attain this purpose, Mrs. Heng S. is seeking a loan to buy an additional cow and some cattle feed. She is a widow with two children, both of whom are students. They also help her with her animal breeding.

loans.use: To buy an additional cow and some cattle feed

loans.name: Sinatai

texts.en:
Sinatai U., age 36, owns and operates a general store, selling a variety of different products in the local community. Sinatai has three years of experience in this business. Sinatai needs a loan of WST $1,500 in order to purchase new items to expand her product offering. She plans to use the earnings from her business (estimated to be 800 talas or US $333 per week) to improve and expand the business. She and her husband have seven children.

This is Sinatai's second loan with SPBD. SPBD's loans are Sinatai's only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with traditional banks.

loans.use: To purchase new items in order to expand her product offering

loans.name: Estrellas De Mayo Group

texts.es:
La B.C. “Estrellas de Mayo” iniciará el ciclo número dos en Pro Mujer, como parte del Centro Focal de Germán Busch.  Está compuesta por ocho integrantes, la banca comunal está dirigida por una mesa directiva y a la cabeza de la misma se encuentra  una presidenta.   Los negocios que las integrantes de la banca comunal llevan adelante son variados: venta de pan, venta de ropa, hilado de lana, trenzado de mantas, tienda surtida, tejido de chompas, venta de ropa de bebe, venta y producción de masitas.

La señora Rosa, presidenta de la banca comunal, indica que forma parte de la B.C. “Estrellas de Mayo”  dos ciclos, aproximadamente  año.  Actualmente casada, madre de dos hijos, su negocio es la atención de una tienda de barrio en su propio domicilio.  Debido al horario de atención que  exige la ateción de una tienda de barrio, desde muy temprano hasta muy tarde, recibe la colaboración de sus hijos.  La señora  María comenta que este negocio nació de su propia inciativa.  Su primer crédito fue de Bs2000 el que está solicitando en esta oportunidad también es de Bs2000, en ambos casos está destinado a ser invertido en la compra de productos para la tienda.

Cuando se le consulta que le gusta de Pro Mujer, ella comenta que le gusta la capacitación.
texts.en: La “Estrellas de Mayo” ["Stars of May"] group is starting its ninth cycle with Pro Mujer, part of the German Busch central office. The group is made up of 8 members and is directed by a board, the head of which is a president. The members of the community bank have various businesses; bread sales, clothing sales, wool,  rug braiding, a store, woven sweaters, baby clothing sales, and the sale and production of pastries. Rosa, the community bank president, says that she has been part of the Estrellas de Mayo group for two cycles, approximately one year. She is a married mother of two children. She has a neighbourhood store in her own home. Given the schedule required to tend to a neighbourhood store, from very early to very late, her children help her. Maria says that this business was born from her own initiative. Her first loan was 2000 Bs., and the loan that she is currently requesting is for 2000 Bs. Both loans were to be invested in the purchase of products for her store. When asked what she likes about Pro Mujer, she replied taht she likes the training.

loans.use: the purchase of groceries

loans.name: Mitai

texts.en:
Mitai P. I. is 53, married, and has six children.  She owns a business venture, selling BBQ (sausage, chicken, and plantains).  Mitai has one year of experience in this business.  Mitai needs a loan of WST $1000 to buy BBQ meat, ketchup, plastic plates, utensils, and coal.  She plans to use the earnings from her business (estimated to be 400 talas or US $167 per week) to improve and expand the business.

In 2010, Mitai joined SPBD.  This is her first loan with SPBD.  SPBD's loans are Mitai's only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan from traditional banks.

loans.use: to buy BBQ meat, ketchup, plastic plates, utensils, and coal

loans.name: Roy

texts.en:
Roy C.'s main source of income comes from providing tricycle transport services (a motorcycle with a passenger cab attached to the side). He is 38 years old, married and has three school-aged children. They are from the village of Taguanao, Aloran, Misamis Occidental. Roy has been in his business for over five years and earns approximately 5,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month.

In 2010, Roy joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve his living conditions and enable him to engage in business activities. Roy is requesting a loan of 20,000 PHP which will be used to purchase tires and other accessories. This will be his first loan from GDMPC. He plans to use additional income to improve and expand his business. 

About GDMPC:
GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase tires and other accessories

loans.name: Pann

texts.en:
Mrs. Pann P. is married.  She was born in 1965.  She lives in Preaek Louk village in Kandal province.  She is a mother of five children.  One of her children is a farmer, another is employed in a copy shop, and the rest attend public school.  She is pictured with her husband.

She and her husband, Mr. Bros Yeng, are farmers.  They own a plot of land where they grow both rice and vegetables to sell and support their family.  Mrs. P. is a rice middleman.  She has had some problems with her plantation because the field has infertile soil, is far away from an irrigation system, and has a lot of insects.  To improve production, Mrs. Pann P. is seeking a loan to buy fertilizer, gasoline, and pesticides.  The remainder of the loan will be used to hire farm laborers.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer, gasoline, and pesticides

loans.name: Serafi

texts.en:
Serafi M. is 38 years of age and married with five children, ages 1 – 20 years. Serafi owns and operates a business selling fried foods in her community. She has two years of experience in this business. Serafi needs a loan of 2,500 talas to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale. She plans to use the profit from her business (estimated to be 400 talas or US $167 per week) to improve and expand the business.

In 2006, Serafi joined SPBD to gain access to financial services. Most of SPBD's clients are unable to borrow from commercial banks because they lack collateral. This is Serafi's 6th loan with SPBD.

loans.use: To purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale

loans.name: Dalagan

texts.en:
Dalagan G. is from the town of Mohon, Aloran, Misamis Occidental.  He is 37 years old and single.  

To make a living, Dalagan owns and operates a food stall that caters to the local community.  While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from the sale of dry goods.  Dalagan is just starting in this business.

In 2010, Dalagan joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Dalagan is requesting his first loan of 15000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell.  He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand his business. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines.  It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte, and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Mao

texts.en:
Mr. Mao C. is a villager in Kbal Chrouy in Kandal province. He is a farmer who owns a small piece of land to grow and sell crops to support his family. He has problems in his field because it has infertile soil, is located far from an irrigation system, and has a lot of insects. 

Mr. Mao C. is applying for a loan to buy fertilizer, gasoline, and pesticide. His wife, Mrs. Cheav Hor Khuy, is a coffee seller in a local village where she is able to earn some money to support the family, too. This couple has five children, two of whom are fruit sellers. The others attend the local public school. His wife is in the picture with him.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer, gasoline, and pesticide.

loans.name: Lach

texts.en: Lach S. is 45 years old, married and devoted to her six children, all of whom are single. Two of them are employed as workers at the garment industry, and have a regular salary every month. Lach S. is married to 49-year-old Sak Sat, who helps support the family by running a motor taxi. Lach S. stays at home to manage the family housework. In addition, Lach S. has built a space behind her house where she raises a few cows for income. Because the cow-raising business is a very profitable one for Lach S. and her family, Lach S. has requested a loan of US$500 in order to buy additional cows to raise for sale.

loans.use: To buy additional cows to raise for sale.

loans.name: Soli

texts.en:
Soli S. is 58 and married with eight children. She raises pigs for sale. Soli has many years of experience in this business. She needs a loan of WST$1250 to purchase additional animals. She plans to use the earnings from her business (estimated to be 600 talas or US $250 per week) to improve and expand the business.

This is Soli's second loan with SPBD. SPBD loans are her only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with traditional banks.

loans.use: To purchase additional animals.

loans.name: Angel

texts.en:
Angel S. is from the village of Gata Daku Clarin Misamis Occidental. He is 46 years old. Angel is married with two adult-aged children. To make a living, Angel owns and operates a tricycle transport service. Angel has been engaged in this business for a year and earns approximately 10000 PHP a month.

In 2004, Angel joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services. Angel has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10000 PHP from GDMPC. He is requesting a new loan of 20000 PHP which will be used to repair his existing vehicle for better service. This loan will be his fourth from GDMPC. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve his family's living conditions. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To repair an existing vehicle for better service.

loans.name: Tae

texts.en:
Tae P. is 48 and married with six children. She provides tailoring services to the local community. Tae has many years of experience in this business. She needs a loan of WST$1950 to purchase additional fabric and materials. She plans to use the earnings (estimated to be 800 talas or US $333 per week) to improve and expand her business.

This is Tae's third loan with SPBD.  SPBD loans are her only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with traditional banks.

loans.use: To purchase additional fabric and materials.

loans.name: Seutaatia

texts.en: Seutaatia T. is 45 and married with five children. She owns a business planting and harvesting taro for sale. She has two years of experience in this business. Seutaatia needs a loan of 1000 talas to invest in expanding the business. She plans to use the earnings from her business (estimated to be 500 talas or US $208 per week) to improve and expand the business. SPBD's loans are Seutaatia's only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with traditional banks. This is her third loan with SPBD.

loans.use: To invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Khana Naira Group

texts.es:
La B.C. “KHANA NAIRA” ( en idioma aymara “ojos claros”) iniciará el ciclo número  uno en Pro Mujer, como parte del Centro Focal de Los Andes.  Está compuesta por once integrantes, la banca comunal está dirigida por una mesa directiva compuesta por una presidenta, una tesorera y una secretaria de actas.   Los negocios que las integrantes de la banca comunal llevan adelante son variados: taller de carpintería, venta de ropa, servicio de filmación, confección de chamarra, repostería, tienda, confección de chamarras, tejido de mantas, promotora de ventas de productos de Yanbal, venta de detergentes, producción de pitas.

La señora  Dora,  presidenta de la banca comunal esta casada y es madre de dos hijos.  Desde hace diez años tiene como negocio la filmación de eventos sociales, recibe el apoyo de su marido y cuando la demanda es mayor les colabora un amigo de la familia.  El esposo trabaja como camarógrafo de prensa, ese conocimiento dio lugar a la inciativa del negocio que ahora tiene, realiza filmaciones de eventos sociales como matrimonios, bautizos, ch´allas, también viaja a poblaciones cercanas a la ciudad de El Alto.  El crédito que ahora  está solicitando será destinado para la compra de una cámara fotográfica y una impresora de fotos.

La señora Dora está contenta de haber encontrado a Pro Mujer, pues logrará el crédito que necesita con pocos requisitos, siente que hay confianza entre las integrantes del grupo y Pro Mujer.
texts.en: The Khana Naira (in the Aymara language, "blue eyes") group has started its first cycle with Pro Mujer, as part of the Los Andes office. It is made up of eleven members and directed by a board made up of a president, treasurer and a secretary. The members have various businesses: a carpentry workshop, clothing sales, a filming service, jacket-making, dessert sales, a store, jacket-making, rug making, Yanbal products promoter and salesperson, detergent sales, and pita-making. Dora, the community bank president, is a married mother of two children. She has had a business where she films social events. Her husband supports her, and when there is great demand a family friend helps out. Her husband works as a news cameraman, and his knowledge led to this business. They film social events such as marriages, baptisms and ch'allas. They also travel to villages near to the El Alto city. The loan that she is now requesting will be used for the purchase of a camera and a photo printer. Dora is happy to have encountered Pro Mujer, as she has obtained this loan with few requirements. She feels that there is confidence between the members of the group and Pro Mujer.

loans.use: the purchase of a camera and photo printer

loans.name: Ros

texts.en: Ros S., 61, is from Phnom Penh, Cambodia.  She is married to Varin, 80.  They are blessed with six children.  Four of them are married and two are single.  Ros S. and her husband depend on their children.  Three of their children work in the garment factory and one is a civil service officer.  Ros S. has an old house that needs repair.  Due to her lack of cash, she decided to ask for a loan through Kiva, which she will use to repair her house.

loans.use: to repair her existing house

loans.name: Socheat

texts.en: Mr. Socheat C. (pictured here) is single and lives with his parents, brothers and sisters along National Road Number One about 17 kilometers from Phnom Penh. He has been a lotus farmer for more than six years. He asked for a Kiva loan one time already. Now he is requesting another loan of $800 to continue his farming business by purchasing seeds, fertilizer and pesticide to maintain the lotus farm.

loans.use: To use for farming.

loans.name: Tolusefulutasi

texts.en:
Tolusefulutasi is 42 and married with six children (aged 5-30 years). Tolusefulutasi owns & operates a business selling bamboo handicrafts to tourists and local community members.  She has two years of experience in this business. Tolusefulutasi needs a loan of WST $2,500 to purchase raw materials to make additional handicrafts.  She plans to use the profit from her business (estimated to be 400 talas per week) to improve/expand her business.

In 2005, Tolusefulutasi joined SPBD to gain access to financial services.  Most of SPBD's clients are unable to borrow from commercial banks, because they lack collateral.  This is Tolusefulutasi's sixth loan with SPBD.

loans.use: To purchase raw materials to make additional handicrafts

loans.name: Florencia

texts.en:
Florencia C. is from the village of Kinuman Norte Ozamiz City, Misamis Occidental.  She is 63 years old.  Florencia is married and has two adult-aged children.  To make a living, Florencia owns and operates a business venture in the agricultural sector raising crops.  While not the only means of generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from planting and harvesting bananas for sale.  Florencia has been engaged in her business for over six years and earns approximately 3000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2007, Florencia joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities.  Florencia is requesting a loan of 8000 PHP which will be used to purchase fertilizers, including manure.  This loan will be the first loan taken out by Florencia from GDMPC.  She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her general living conditions.

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte, and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks, and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizer, including manure

loans.name: Chhuneng

texts.en:
Mrs. Chhuneng C. (pictured with her loom), 41 years old, and her husband, Mr. Sokun Sam,  44 years old, live on an Island in the Mekong River about 15  kilometers from Phnom Penh, the capital city of Cambodia. They have been married since 1990 and have three children: one son and two daughters.    

Chhuneng has been a silk weaver since she was 16 years old. This is a skill she learned from her mother. She sells her finished products to a middleman in the village who then takes them to sell in a Phnom Penh market. 

She is requesting her first loan of $200 to purchase silk materials for her silk weaving business.

loans.use: To purchase silk materials for her silk weaving business.

loans.name: Phorn

texts.en: Mrs. Phorn R. lives in Trapeang Chrey village in Kandal province. She was born in 1963. She is a sail, rice, and bean middleman who earns some profit to support her family. Her husband, Mr. Dam Kun, is a farmer who owns a plot of land where he grows crops to sell to support his family. On the plantation, it is time to grow beans, but he does not have enough money.  So to improve this purpose, Mrs. Phorn R. is applying for a loan to buy bean seeds, pesticide, a and a pesticide sprayer, and to hire farming laborers to grow beans. She is a mother of seven children, two of whom are laborers, three are enrolled in the local public school and the youngest two are just six and five years old. Her husband appears in picture with her.

loans.use: To buy bean seeds, pesticide, and a pesticide sprayer

loans.name: Sokhoeurn

texts.en:
Mrs. Sokhoeurn L. (pictured here) and her husband, Mr. Bros Khvan, were married in 1997 and have one son and two daughters. They live aL. National Road Number 1, about 15 kilometers from Phnom Penh, the capital of Cambodia. 

Mrs. Sokhoeurn L. has been producing rice wine and raising pigs for more than 12 years. Her husband is a driver. A recipient of a previous Kiva loan, she is now requesting another loan of $1,200 to organize her house by laying bricks and plastering the ceiling and the wall in order to visually enhance it.

loans.use: To lay brick and plaster the ceiling and the wall of her house.

loans.name: Oldalia

texts.en:
Oldalia M. is from the village of Segatic Daku Clarin, Misamis Occidental. She is 37 years old.  Oldalia is married and has five school-aged children. To make a living, Oldalia owns and operates a business venture in the retail sector running a general store.  While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from selling a variety of products in the local community.  Oldalia has been engaged in her business for over a year and earns approximately 10000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2010, Oldalia joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Oldalia has successfully repaid a previous loan of 20000 PHP from GDMPC.  This previous loan was used to coconut shells. Oldalia is requesting a new loan of 35000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell.  This loan will be the third loan taken out by Oldalia from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of the borrower's family. 

About GDMPC:
GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines.  It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte, and Misamis Occidental.  Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolk, and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Mrs. Sao Chantha Village Bank Group

texts.en: This village bank loan consists of 11 people who live in Preaek Traeng village in Kandal province. Mrs. Sao C. is the village bank president who has been selected by the other members. The members will use their portion of the loan for different purposes to improve their family living. She is a vegetable seller in the local market where she is able to earn some money to support her family. Since her business is going well, she wants to expand. Therefore, Mrs. Sao C. is requesting a loan to buy more vegetables to resell. Her husband, Mr. Moeun S., is a teacher in the local school who gets a small salary to support his family. This couple has three children, one of whom is a construction worker, one is employed in pure water production and the other is a student.

loans.use: To buy more vegetables

loans.name: Vivian

texts.en:
Vivian B. is from the city of BACOLOD OZAMIZ CITY. She is 53 years old, married and has 4 adult children. Vivian owns & operates an agricultural business, planting & harvesting  a variety of vegetables for sale. She has been engaged in her business for over 10 years and earns approximately 2,500 PHP a month.

In 2007, Vivian joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from GDMPC. Vivian is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional seedlings and fertilizer for garden maintenance. This will be her third loan from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve her family's general living conditions. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fishermen and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional seedlings and fertilizer

loans.name: Man

texts.en:
Mr. Man N. is 44 years old and his wife, Mrs. Sipiyas Ber (pictured together), is 41 years old. They live along National Road Number Six, about twenty kilometers from Phnom Penh, the capital city of Cambodia. They have six children: three sons and three daughters. One is a fisherman, one is a garment factory worker, two attend school and other two are still young. 

Man is a carpenter and he also fishes when he is free. He is requesting his first loan of $800 to purchase materials and to pay for house renovation costs.

loans.use: To purchase materials and pay for house renovation costs

loans.name: Meng

texts.en:
Mr. Meng P. (shown in the photo) and his wife, Mrs. Chan Lach, live along National Road Number 1, about 15 kilometers from Phnom Penh City. They have been farming for fifteen years. They have been married since 1980 and have seven children: six sons and one daughter. 

Meng has previously requested a Kiva loan. He hopes to continue increasing his productivity so he is asking for another loan of $1,000 to purchase seed, fertilizer and pesticide.

loans.use: To purchase farm inputs

loans.name: Lam's Group

texts.en:
Anlong Slat village, Kandal province, is the location of this four member group loan, led by Mrs. Lam P.. They will each use their portion of the loan for different purposes to improve their families' living conditions. 

Mrs. Lam P. is a white wine maker and pig breeder who is able to earn some money to support her family. Since her business is going well, she wants to expand. Mrs. Lam P. is, therefore, applying for a loan to buy more rice for making white wine. She will use the rest of the loan to buy more pig food. 

Her husband, Mr. Sung Toem, is a farmer who owns 2-hectare plot of land to grow rice to sell to support his family. He is also a fisherman. Through these activities, they support four children, two of whom are attending the local public school, while the others are too young to work or study.

loans.use: To buy more rice for making white wine

loans.name: Sony

texts.en:
Mrs. Sony S. (shown in the photo) and her husband, Mr. Samath Sao, live in a village along the Mekong River, about 15 kilometers northeast of Phnom Penh. They have been married since 1990 and have three children: one son and two daughters. All of them are in school: two are attending universities. Mr. Samath Sao is a weaver. 

Sony runs a grocery store from home. She also assists in her husband’s weaving business when she is free. She is asking for a loan of $1,200 to pay for her children's education fees. She will also use a part of the loan to purchase weaving materials.

loans.use: To pay her children's education fees and to purchase weaving materials

loans.name: Rachana

texts.en:
Mrs. Rachana Y. (in the photo) is 25 years old and her husband, Mr. Sarum Sim, is 26 years old. They live along National Road Number 1 about 35 kilometers from Phnom Penh. The couple has been married since 2003 and has two children: one young son and one daughter who attends school. Rachana stays at home and does the housework. The main source of income is from her husband’s business. He is a carpenter.

Rachana is asking for her first loan of $1,000 to repair the house where she lives and to buy a new motorbike. The old motorbike breaks very often, is costly to repair and uses more gasoline than newer motorbikes.

loans.use: To repair the house where she lives and to buy a new motorbike

loans.name: Lourdesita

texts.en: Lourdesita N.'s main source of income comes from harvesting and selling ocean-caught fish in her community. She is 52 years old, married and has eight grown-up children. She is from the village of Punta, Pana-on, Misamis Occidental. Lourdesita has been in her fishing business for over 20 years and earns approximately 2,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month. In 2008, Lourdesita joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living conditions and enable her to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from GDMPC. Lourdesita is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase fishing equipment including hooks and nets. This will be her third loan from GDMPC. She plans to use additional income to improve and expand her business. About GDMPC: GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs. Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase fishing equipment including hooks and nets

loans.name: Hum's Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Hum Y. and her husband, Mr. Samoeun Horm, are farmers who own a plot of land where they grow rice and beans to sell to support their family. He also sells ice cream door-to-door. It is time for planting, but she does not have enough money to support the rice and bean field. To improve production, Mrs. Hum Y. is asking for a loan to buy rice and bean seed. She is the mother of four children: two of whom are ice cream sellers but the others are attending the local public school.

This group, which consists of five people, is led by Mrs. Hum Y. of Preaek Louk village in Kandal province. Their loans will be used in various ways to improve their standard of living.

loans.use: To buy rice and bean seed

loans.name: Thoeurk

texts.en:
Mr. Thoeurk T. (pictured with his wife) is 46 years old and his wife, Mrs. Kong Lor, is 50 years old. They live in a small village along National Road Number three about twenty kilometers from Phnom Penh City. They have four daughters: two are garment factory workers, one attends school and the other one is still young. 
 
Thoeurk and her husband sell Cambodian cakes in the village. They buy ingredients from the market and make the cakes by themselves. 
Thoeurk is requesting his first loan of US$500 to add to his own money to purchase a motorbike for commuting.

loans.use: To add to his own money to purchase a motorbike for commuting.

loans.name: Maridel

texts.en:
Maridel M. is from the village of Punta, Pana-on, Misamis Occidental. She is 48 years old, married and has 2 adult children.
